Title: "Utilizing search.score for Sorting in Azure AI Search"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdfEven when youdo use $orderby, the relevance score is used to break ties by default. However,sometimes it's useful to use the relevance score as an initial sort criteria, and some othercriteria as the tie-breaker. The example in this article demonstrates using thesearch.score function for sorting.
The syntax for search.score in $orderby is search.score(). The function search.scoredoesn't take any parameters. It can be used with the asc or desc sort-order specifier,just like any other clause in the $orderby parameter. Mostcommonly, OData expressions are used for the $orderby and $filter parameters.These expressions can be complex, containing multiple clauses, functions, andoperators. However, even simple OData expressions like property paths are used inmany parts of the Azure AI Search REST API. For example, path expressions are used torefer to subfields of complex fields everywhere in the API, such as when listing subfieldsin a suggester, a scoring function, the $select parameter, or even fielded search inLucene queries.
